B. ASCII: Display printable characters in ASCII format; non-printable characters as '.' (period character).
C. Hex: Display all characters in hexadecimal format (two-digit hex values preceded by the escape code \x).

Default Analog Format 1. Open Simpl Debugger tool and connect with Control System 2. Go to Debugging Settings option one next to help on Crestron Toolbox 3. select "Default Analog Format" option and select the available option

1. Selected Analog Format have information as, A. Signed: Signed decimal format. B. Time: # hours, # minutes, #.## seconds. C. Unsigned: Unsigned decimal format. D. Hex: "####h" format - Four-digit hexadecimal value followed by the "h" specifier. E. Percent: Percentage from 0.000% to 100.000%.

Ctrl + C Copies 1. Open Simpl Debugger tool and connect with Control System 2. Go to Debugging Settings option one next to help on Crestron Toolbox 3. select "Ctrl + C Copies" option and select the available option 4. From Trace window select any signal and press Ctrl+C >> open text file and paste 5. repeat same process with other available options of CTRL+C

1. when Name only option was selected, only signal name should display on text file after paste 2. Should display signal information in TIME/VALUE/NAME format when selected other options "Signal Time/value/name" option

Timestamp Configuration 1. Open Simpl Debugger tool and connect with Control System 2. Go to Debugging Settings option one next to help on Crestron Toolbox 3. select "Timestamp Configuration" option OR, 1. Open SimplDebugger Tool and Connect with Control system. 2. click down arrow next to the INSERT Timestamp button and select "setup" option

1. User should have control to type the desired label in the default comment field 2. Click Text to selec the color of the text 3. Click Background to select the background Color 4. Repeat steps 1 - 3 for each time stamp user want to edit 5. to revert back to the default colors and text click Load Default
Reported issue Toolbx-263, can't repro with this TB build as well
Save current logging 1. Open Simpl Debugger Tool and connect with Control System 2. go to Logging option; last option on crestron toolbox menu bar list. 3. click Save current option
1. should able to save the logging file by typing an optional Quick Name and filename, selecting Folder to locate the target directory.
Start logging 1. Open Simpl Debugger Tool and connect with Control System 2. go to Logging option; last option on crestron toolbox menu bar list. 3. click Start logging option
1. User should be able to start looging by following as shown below, A. Type an optional Quick Name and filename. B. Click Select Folder to locate the target directory. C. Click OK.
Stop logging 1. Open Simpl Debugger Tool and connect with Control System 2. go to Logging option; last option on crestron toolbox menu bar list. 3. click Stop logging option
1. should stop the currently running Logging sesion.

1. Open Simpl Debugger Tool and connect with Control System 2. From Debugging Setting >> Default analog format >> select one of the option from the list (signed, unsigned, percent and hexadecimal) 3. From the signal Tree view, select the analog signal 4. type the desired analog value or select a previously entered value from the history (drop-down) list 5. Click Send button 6. Repeat same process for all the available options of analog as mentioned in step 2)
Note: 1. include hexadecimal values greater than 81 (example 82, 83 ...,99) while sending anlog values 2. signed value higher than 32767 will start to display the value with negative number (example if you send 32768, then trace window will display -32768) 3. for unsigned value higher than 65535 will display the value starting from 0. (example sending 65536 will display the value 0)

1. verify the sent entered value will display in Trace Window View with its respective Analog Join
NOTE:- if user do not add a specifier (e.g. %, d or h) the value is assumed to be decimal

1. Open Simpl Debugger Tool and connect with Control System 2. From Debugging Setting >> Default serial format >> select one of the option from the list [Mix(ASCII/HEX), ASCII and Hexadecimal] 3. From the signal Tree view, select the serial signal 4. type the desired analog value or select a previously entered value from the history (drop-down) list 5. Click Send button 6. Repeat same process for all the available options of serial as mentioned in step 2)
Note: - include hexadecimal null character while verifying serial signal (example: \xA1\x81\x44\x00\x83\x93..)
1. The sent serial value or string of characters will display in Trace Window with its respective Serial Join

1. Open Simpl Debugger Tool and connect with Control System 2. From the signal Tree view, select the Digital signal 3. Click the buton that corresponds to the desired Signal state as follows A. press high wave pattern B. press low wave pattern C. press pulse high wave pattern D. press pulse low wave pattern
1. Depends upon the selected wave pattern, Trace window view will display the signal with its status on the respective Digital Signal Joins

Normal Close of Simpl Debugger Tool
1. Setup the Simpl debugger tool and run the program normally 2. Close the Simpl Debugger tool (X on the debugger window)

1. Depending on the load of the PC and the process user may or may not get a Toolbox message saying that the debugger is waiting for the control system to exit debug mode, eventually, the debugger should exit or change the connection status
2. should exit out Simpl Debugger Tool smoothly and shouldn't freeze
Normal Close of Toolbox while running Simpl Debugger
1. Setup the Simpl debugger tool and run the program normally 2. Close Toolbox (X on the Toolbox window)

1. Depending on the load of the PC and the process user may or may not get a Toolbox message saying that the debugger is waiting for the control system to exit debug mode, eventually, the debugger should exit or change the connection status
2. TB should close smoothly with out freezing and TB shouldn't close
Disconnect connection while using Ethernet and USB connection (both)
1. Setup the Simpl Debugger Tool and run the program normally 2. Disconnect the Ethernet or USB conncetion
1. Wait 1 - 5 mins depends on the program load, message should pops up saying that the connection to the controller has been lost 2. user should restart the debugger and possibly reboot the device
Doesn't display any message (waited roughly around 3 mins). However, connection stataus display as disconnected
Disconnect connection and then attempt to close the debugger
1. Setup the Simpl Debugger Tool and run the program normally 2. Disconnect the connection from the controller (both Ethernet or USB type) 3. Attempt to close the Simpl Debugger window

1. User should be able to close the debugger window until a message posp up saying that the connection to the control system was lost and that the debugger cannot request the control system to exit debug mode and that may have to reboot the controller 2. Message will pops up depends upon the program load. 3. TB shouldn't freeze nor crashed
Resend the Program while debugging on 3 series Control system
1. Open Simple Debugger Tool and Run the program normally 2. resend the program to the controller (no need to recompile the program, just resend the program)

1. should pops up a message saying that the controller has exited debugging mode and will ask if the user would like to reload the program. 2. Answer Yes and make sure the debugger re-initializes the program and resume debugging 3. During these process, Simpl debugger shouldn't freeze 4. TB shouldn't crashed

Program stopped and doesn't display the program get restart on simpl debugger. Example if you have a oscillator in your program, after resending that program (or restarting) program won't run in Simpl debugger tool
Resend the Program while debugging on 2 series Control system
1. Open Simple Debugger Tool and Run the program normally 2. recompiling the program and transfer to the controller

1. Should pops up a message saying that the .sig file has changed and will ask if the user would like to reload the program. 2. Answer Yes and make the debugger initializes the program and resumes debugging 3. During these process, Simpl debugger shouldn't freeze 4. TB shouldn't crashed

toolbox crashes when you go on the input settings tab

Verify that adjusting settings makes changes in real time with secondary instance of the tool and affects outputted audio 4. Ensure that selected input shows correct state of the input signal

Verify that adjusting settings makes changes in real time with secondary instance of the tool and affects outputted audio 3. Ensure that adjusting speaker parameters in this tab reflects the same as Speaker Adjustments 4. Ensure that each filter of the speaker can be adjusted and the buttons perform the specified actions

1. Open HD-XSP Tool and connect to device/create offline connection 2. Click "Output Settings" tab in Configuration Tools section 3. Chose either Mains or Downmix option 4. Adjust the sliders, combo boxes, and checkbox values

1. Ensure that settings for selected output are displayed based on button selected 2. Verify that adjusting settings makes changes in real time with secondary instance of the tool and affects outputted audio

1. Open HD-XSP Tool and create offline connection 2. Adjust the speaker configuration 2. Use File>>Save Configuration 3. Use File>>Close Session 4. Connect to device 5. Use File>>Load Configuration 6. Use File>>Close Session

1. Verify that configuration file can be saved from offline session 2. Ensure that "Close Session" brings user back to connection page 3. Verify that configuration file can be loaded onto online session 4. Verify that speaker configuration changes are reflected

1. WHILE LOADING CONFIGURATION DEVICE GOT DISCONNECTED and didn't load the saved profile 2. Monitor selection won't retrieve as it was save in the profile (Status and Control >> Downmix volume>>Monitor and main volume >> Monitor)

3. Toolbox crash when re-connecting to device using HD-XSP Tool with "Use last device"

When "Restore Factory Defaults" is used, warning dialog appears stating what will happen when restoring 3. After restore, connection can be made to device and all settings are set to factory defaults

1. Tool connects succesfully to the device 2. "Status And Control" tab is visible
Status And Control --> Zone and Source Selection

1. Open Sonnex Tool and connect to device 2. In "Status And Control" tab, select the audio zone to adjust by selecting it from the drop-down list. 3. Select the source that will be switched to the selected audio zone from Source drop-down list 4. click Mute button to toggle the mute setting on and off for the currently selected zone 5. Save and Load Configuration to verify the setting

1. Ensure that zone and source list includes all inputs/outputs expected (including the extenders) 2. When routed, ensure that volume/mute can be applied 3. The mute button will turn red to indicate that audio is muted. 4. Verify if change is made to all zones, it is reflected 5. Should be able to save the set profile and load correctly.

1. saw this intermittent issue once while using TB v3.07.226 2. Saw reported issue Toolbx-675 using TB v3.0930.0042 as well 3. changing zone and source from theirs drop-down menu from "Zone and source selection" section from one instance of toolbox doesn't change in open instance of another toolbox. Note:- changes on All Zones were visible in another instance of toolbox
1. swamp - Unmuted a Zone While All Zones Are Muted Improperly Reflects Current Mute State

1. Open Sonnex Tool and connect to device 2. In "Status And Control" tab, click "Bussing…" button 3. To add a zone to the selected bus, click the zone name in the Zones list to select it, and then click Add to Bus. 4. To remove a zone from the selected bus, click the zone name in the Output Bus list box to select it, and click Remove from Bus. 5. Select an output bus and Click "remove All Zones from Bus" 5. click "Remove all zones from all busses"

1. Should Open Bussing Configuration dialogue 2. Should be able to add and remove 3. If the selected zone was previously assigned to a bus, the bus number will be displayed after the zone name. Adding the zone to a new bus will disconnect it from the previously assigned bus 4. Bussed zones will share source selection, volume level, and startup zone settings 5. Remove All zones from bus option will only remove all zones from selected Output bus 6. Bridged zones audio adjustments will be applied equally to both zones 7. Should remove all zones from all output busses by clicing " remove all zones from all busses",
assigning zones to output Bus don't prompt user for already assigned the selected zone.

1. Open Sonnex Tool and connect to device 2. In "Status And Control" tab, click "Bridging…" button 3. click the check box corresponding to each pair you want to bridge 4. verify un-checking of selected bridged pair
1. SHould open Bridging Configuration dialogue 2. Should able to pair the desire bridge and un-selecting should un do bridge pairing
1. Open Sonnex Tool and connect to device 2. In "Status And Control" tab, Use the slider to adjust the overall volume level at the currnetly selected audio zone
1. Zone volume should be enable when any audio source signal is selected 2. When enable, should be able to slide the volume level

1. Open Sonnex Tool and connect to device 2. In "Status And Control" tab from All Zones section. 3. Mute All: Click Mute All button to toggle the mute setting on and off for all zones. 4. Select the desired tone profile from the drop-down list. >>Click Apply Tone Profile To All Zones. >> Click Yes to confirm the operation, or No to cancel out. 5. Click on the Doorbell Source drop-drop and select the applicable Doorbell Source

1. The Mute All button will turn red to indicate that all audio is muted. 2. Tone Profile drop-down should have an option. Should be able to display the information of selected Tone Profile 3. Doorbell Source dropdown should be enable and user should be able to select available options
1. Open Sonnex Tool and connect to device 2. Go to "System Status" tab 3. Toggle front panel switch on the device
1. Verify that the SWAMP and it extenders are listed with valid connections 2. Ensure that toggling the front panel switch on device is reflected 3. Ensure the extenders have a valid audio link
1. Open Sonnex Tool and connect to device 2. Click "Source Settings" button to make "Source Compensation" appear 3. Adjust the sliders and values from all available source sliders

1. Ensure that all 24 sources have sliders that can be adjusted 2. When source is selected, if audio source is playing then verify that signal information is displayed 3. Ensure adjusting the sliders and values are retained

1. Open Sonnex Tool and connect to device 2. Click "Zone Settings" button to make "Audio Adjustments" appear 3. Change the available controls under Volume, Tone, Balance, Sonnex Speaker Protect and Bell volume section 4. Verify the changes persist after visiting back to same setting
1. controls should be enable and user should have control to change 2. change should stay after vising the that the zone specific values can be changed and retained for the various zones

1. Open Sonnex Tool and connect to device 2. Click "Zone Settings" button then click "System Eqs" tab 3. Acknowledge the NVIDIA warning is still enabled 4. Using "Status And Control", route a zone to a source 5. Select EQ button on left side 6. If Graphic EQ, adjust the slider values 7. If Parametric EQ, adjust the filter values for each active filter of the speaker 8. If Speaker Profiles, either load from file or use Crestron Preset. Then chose speaker and apply to zone/all zones

1. Ensure that Graphic Eqs displays sliders for each frequency bands while Parametric displays a graph while Speaker Profiles displays buttons and text boxes for the speaker profile information 2. Verify that adjusting settings makes changes in real time with secondary instance of the tool and affects outputted audio 3. Verify that Speaker changes are reflected in the audio adjustments tab

1. Open Sonnex Tool and connect to device 2. Click "Zone Settings" button then click "Output Bussing" tab 3. Create buses from "Status And Control" tab's button 4. Select output bus from combo box 5. Select Zone from within bus 6. Adjust the output bus volume offset

1. Verify that the bussing list from "Status And Control" and from "Output Bussing" match 2. Ensure that when a zone is clicked from within a bus, that the zone is routed to in "Status And Control" 3. Ensure that offset slider only affects the specific zone and is zone independent
1. Open Sonnex Tool and connect to device 2. Click "Zone Settings" button then click "Fault Status" tab 3. Using "Status And Control", route a zone to a source

1. Ensure that the fault status is independent for each zone 2. Verify that there are no faults found in connection 3. Expects data for Current, Voltage, Temperature, DC Offset, and Output Signal Clipping 4. If SPDIF is selected, message is displayed stating "Fault information is not applicable for unamplified digital outputs"

1. Open Sonnex Tool and connect to device 2. Click "Configuration..." button (top right corner) 3. Click "Save" button to save current configuration 4. Use "Save As" dialog to save off a .SNX file 5. Ensure that restore has message indicating that device was restore succesfully 4. Verify device was restored to default settings 5. Ensure that progress bar appears and message appears indicating that load was successful 6. Verify that saved configuration settings are applied

Cell.Data: verify DIN-THSTAT via Device discovery tool.
1. Connect the DIN-THSTAT device with PC via USB connection. 2. Open Device Discovery Tool
make sure device display with correct Model Name, hostname, firmware and connection type
Cannot repro the reported issue Toolbx- 3931 using Tb v3.07.142. Since bug was in dev status, can't change to fix close state
verify DIN-THSTAT via easy config, System Info, Text console etc…
1. Open Easy config, System info, Text console, etc… tools and connect with DIN-THSTAT device
device should connect with respective tools and display the correct information
1. Open Toolbox and select Thermostat Configuration Tool from Tools options 2. Create a shortcut for Thermostat Configuration Tool and open from its respective icon

1. Should open a new dialog "Thermostat configuration" which contains: A. five tabs: System, Settings, Display, Setpoint Limits and Sensor B. Three buttons: Relay Tests, Load from Device, and Send to Device C. One File Menu which have following options I. New II. Open III. Save IV. Save As V. Load from Device VI. Send to Device VII. Preference VIII. Close

Space System Type: 1. Open Thermostat Configuration tool 2. select System Tab 3. Select any available option from Space system Type drop down menu 4. Send to Device 5. Repeat same steps for other available options on Space system Type
Note:- 1. Open text console to connect with repective device to check the device response while selecting different options type.

0. By default dropdown options should select the "Heat/Cool" options 1. Should able to set the selected option type for Space System Type from following options A. None B. Heat/Cool C. Heat pump w/Aux Heat D. Dual-fuel Heat Pump 2. Verify by closing and reopening tool to check device set with selected Space System Type each time. 3. Monitor the text console of a device, sending different command while selecting difffernt option

Floor Radiant Heat System Type 1. Open Thermostat Configuration Tool 2. select System Tab 3. Select one option from Floor Radiant Heat System Type drop down menu 4. Send to Device 5. Repeat same steps for other available options on Floor Radiant Heat system drop down menu.
Note:- 1. Open text console to connect with repective device to check the device response while selecting different options type.

0. By default dropdown menu should select "None" options 1. Should able to set the selected option type for Floor Radiant Heat System Type from its available options A. None B. Floor Waring C. Space Heat D. Both 2. Verify by closing and reopening tool to check device set with selected Floor Radiant Heat System Type each time. 3. Monitor the text console of a device, sending different command while selecting difffernt option

Note:- 1. Space Heat Stages fields are only required when space system type is heat. 2. Open text console to connect with repective device to check the device response while selecting different options type.

Heat Pump Balance Point Temp 1. Open Thermostat Configuration Tool 2. select System Tab 3. Enable by selecting checkbox option (if previously disabled) 4. Set temperature in the respective text filed 5. Send to Device
Note:- 1. Heat pump balance point temperature must be below aux heat balance point temperature when space system type is heat pump/aux 2. Heat pump balance point field required when space system type is either type of heat pump. 3. Open text console to connect with repective device to check the device response while selecting different options type.

0. By default options should be disable 1. Range of value set should be between A. In Fahrenheit - 0 to 90 in 1 degree increment B. In Celsius - 18 to 32 in 1 dregree increment 2. Should able to toggle to enable/disable Heat Pump Balance Point Temp 3. Respective text filed to set the temperature should be enable only if the checkbox option was enabled. 4. Verify by closing and reopening tool to check device set with selected Heat Pump Balance Point Temp each time. 5. Monitor the text console of a device, sending different command while selecting difffernt option
Note:- 1. If increment or decrement were higher and lower than its limit then text field will be disabled 2. Unit conversion between F to C and viceversa is not correct with the standard conversions
1. clicking new doesn't cleared the value in HEAT PUMP and AUX. balance.

Aux Balance Point Temp 1. Open Thermostat Configuration Tool 2. select System Tab 3. Enable by selecting checkbox option (if previously disabled) 4. Set temperature in respective text filed of Aux Balance Point Temp 5. Send to Device 5. Repeat same steps for setting temperature on Aux Balance Point Temp by setting temperature as A. Lowest available option B. Highest available option C. Middle range available option D. in between Middle and lowest available option E. in between Middle and Highest available option
Note:- 1.Aux heat balance point temperature must always be above the heat pump balance point temperature 2. Aux heat balance point field is required when space system type is heat pump with aux heat 3. Open text console to connect with repective device to check the device response while selecting different options type.

0. By default options should be disable 1. Range of value set should be between A. In Fahrenheit - 0 to 90 in 1 degree increment B. In Celsius - 18 to 32 in 1 dregree increment 2. Should able to toggle to enable/disable Aux Balance Point Temp 3. Respective text filed to set the temperature should be enable only if the checkbox option was enabled 4. Verify by closing and reopening tool to check device set with selected Aux Balance Point Temp each time. 5. Monitor the text console of a device, sending different command while selecting difffernt option
Note:- If increment or decrement were higher and lower than its limit then text field will be disabled

Note: If Heat pump balance were enabled and have certain value set, and then enable Aux. Balance then the value of Heat pump set changed to 0.
Value of Heat pump can't be greater than Aux. Balance due to which value changed on Heat pump changed while performing above step.
